title: Neilson Poe (American football)
text:
Neilson Poe (October 1, 1876 – September 22, 1963) a.k.a. Net Poe was a <a href="American%20football">football</a> player for the <a href="Princeton%20Tigers">Princeton Tigers</a>. He played in the Princeton <a href="backfield">backfield</a> in 1895 and 1896, and even later returned to coach football at the school. He was also one of the <a href="Poe%20brothers">Poe brothers</a>, six siblings who were celebrated football players at Princeton University from 1882 until 1901. Neilson graduated from Princeton in 1897.
During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, Neilson served in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> <a href="infantry">infantry</a> as a <a href="lieutenant">lieutenant</a>. In 1917, at the age of 41, he reported for officers training, located in <a href="Plattsburgh%20%28city%29%2C%20New%20York">Plattsburgh, New York</a>. In 1918, Neilson took part in the <a href="Second%20Battle%20of%20the%20Marne">Second Battle of the Marne</a>, during which his commanding officer was killed. During the battle he was wounded, but still took command of his fellow soldiers and safely entrenched them for 24 hours. He suffered a bullet wound to the stomach and several shrapnel wounds. He spent the rest of the war hospitalized and was later awarded the <a href="Croix%20de%20guerre">French War Cross</a> and the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Cross%20%28United%20States%29">Distinguished Service Cross</a>.
After the war, he returned to Princeton to serve as an assistant coach from 1919 until his death in 1963. He resided during those years in the <a href="Nassau%20Inn">Nassau Inn</a>, room 24.
